tier.item: b. ü "Ce n'est pas la route qui est sous eau, c'est LE CAMION QUI N'EST PLUS SUR LA ROUTE!"
The fact that the phonological level isn't available for the logical negation isn't surprising: the entire
phonological domain is opaque to the syntactic rules (though the reverse isn't true).
Maurice Maréchal, L'affaire Frick , Spirou n° 2513, 10.06.86, plate 7.
Maurice Tillieux, Le Chinois à deux roues, Dupuis, 1967, front cover.
© 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier - 71 -
A FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
`It's not the road which is under the water, it's THE TRUCK THAT IS NO LONGER ON THE ROAD !'

of So, be used by who wants.'

tier.item: (182) Né solo in vece di Cosí, ma ancora in vece di Che, la pose il Boccaccio piú volte [...]: [...] non si ritenne
di correre, sí fu a Castel Guiglielmo, in luogo di dire: non si ritenne di correre, che fu a Castel
Guiglielmo; e ancora, [...] io ho messo il capo sotto, né mai ho avuto ardir di trarlo fuori, sí è stato dí
chiaro.
`And not only instead of So, but also instead of That, Boccaccio used it more than once: he didn't refrain
from running, sí he was at Castel Guiglielmo, instead of saying: he didn't refrain from running, that he
was at Castel Guiglielmo; and also I've put my head underneath, and I never dared to take it out, sí there
was daylight.'
(182) Né solo in vece di Cosí, ma ancora in vece di Che, la pose il Boccaccio piú volte [...]: [...] non si ritenne
di correre, sí fu a Castel Guiglielmo, in luogo di dire: non si ritenne di correre, che fu a Castel
Guiglielmo; e ancora, [...] io ho messo il capo sotto, né mai ho avuto ardir di trarlo fuori, sí è stato dí
chiaro.
`And not only instead of So, but also instead of That, Boccaccio used it more than once: he didn't refrain
from running, sí he was at Castel Guiglielmo, instead of saying: he didn't refrain from running, that he
was at Castel Guiglielmo; and also I've put my head underneath, and I never dared to take it out, sí there
was daylight.'

Né solo in vece di Cosí, ma ancora in vece di Che, la pose il Boccaccio piú volte [...]: [...] non si ritenne di correre, sí fu a Castel Guiglielmo, in luogo di dire: non si ritenne di correre, che fu a Castel Guiglielmo; e ancora, [...] io ho messo il capo sotto, né mai ho avuto ardir di trarlo fuori, sí è stato dí chiaro.

And not only instead of So, but also instead of That, Boccaccio used it more than once: he didn't refrain from running, sí he was at Castel Guiglielmo, instead of saying: he didn't refrain from running, that he was at Castel Guiglielmo; and also I've put my head underneath, and I never dared to take it out, sí there was daylight.

tier.item: (204) Avec une partie, une petite partie, une grande partie, l'accord du verbe se fait aujourd'hui soit avec le
collectif, soit avec son complément, et dépend de l'intention de celui qui parle ou qui écrit: Une petite
partie des dettes fut payée avec la part d'héritage. Une partie des domestiques avaient quitté l'hôtel (M.
Maindron, Dariolette, 286; cité par Grevisse).
`With a part, a little part, a great part, verbal agreement is done nowadays either with the collective
noun, or with its complement, depending on the intention of who speaks or writes: A little part of the
debts was paid with the inheritance part. A part of the servants had-PL left the hotel (M. Maindron,
Dariolette, 286; quoted by Grevisse).'
(204) Avec une partie, une petite partie, une grande partie, l'accord du verbe se fait aujourd'hui soit avec le
collectif, soit avec son complément, et dépend de l'intention de celui qui parle ou qui écrit: Une petite
partie des dettes fut payée avec la part d'héritage. Une partie des domestiques avaient quitté l'hôtel (M.
Maindron, Dariolette, 286; cité par Grevisse).
`With a part, a little part, a great part, verbal agreement is done nowadays either with the collective
noun, or with its complement, depending on the intention of who speaks or writes: A little part of the
debts was paid with the inheritance part. A part of the servants had-PL left the hotel (M. Maindron,
Dariolette, 286; quoted by Grevisse).'
Avec une partie, une petite partie, une grande partie, l'accord du verbe se fait aujourd'hui soit avec le
collectif, soit avec son complément, et dépend de l'intention de celui qui parle ou qui écrit: Une petite
partie des dettes fut payée avec la part d'héritage. Une partie des domestiques avaient quitté l'hôtel (M. Maindron, Dariolette, 286; cité par Grevisse).

With a part, a little part, a great part, verbal agreement is done nowadays either with the collective noun, or with its complement, depending on the intention of who speaks or writes: A little part of the debts was paid with the inheritance part. A part of the servants had-PL left the hotel (M. Maindron, Dariolette, 286; quoted by Grevisse).

tier.item: (229) Ripetiamo: è meglio non concordare quando il verbo viene prima del complemento. Ma bisogna tener
conto di una sfumatura di pensiero e di stile. Se nella costruzione normale verbo + complemento si ha la
concordanza, può darsi che l'autore abbia voluto dare una particolare intensità al participio, diminuendo il
valore del verbo come azione e spostando il participio verso la sfera dell'aggettivo. In parole piú semplici,
e con un esempio: di fronte a "Egli ha spento la sigaretta", azione pura, "Egli ha spenta la sigaretta" viene
a significare quasi "Egli tiene spenta la sigaretta", cioè "Egli ha la sigaretta spenta".
`We repeat: it's better to not agree when the verb comes before the complement. But one has to consider a
shade of thought and style. If in the normal construct verb + complement one finds agreement, it can be
the case that the author wished to give a particular intensity to the participle, reducing the valor of the
verb as action and shifting the participle towards the adjectival sphere. In simplest words, and with an
example: in the face of "He has extinguished-M the cigarette", mere action, "He has extinguished-F the
cigarette" turns to signify nearly "He holds extinguished-F the cigarette", that's to say "He has the
cigarette extinguished-F".'
(229) Ripetiamo: è meglio non concordare quando il verbo viene prima del complemento. Ma bisogna tener
conto di una sfumatura di pensiero e di stile. Se nella costruzione normale verbo + complemento si ha la
concordanza, può darsi che l'autore abbia voluto dare una particolare intensità al participio, diminuendo il
valore del verbo come azione e spostando il participio verso la sfera dell'aggettivo. In parole piú semplici,
e con un esempio: di fronte a "Egli ha spento la sigaretta", azione pura, "Egli ha spenta la sigaretta" viene
a significare quasi "Egli tiene spenta la sigaretta", cioè "Egli ha la sigaretta spenta".
`We repeat: it's better to not agree when the verb comes before the complement. But one has to consider a
shade of thought and style. If in the normal construct verb + complement one finds agreement, it can be
the case that the author wished to give a particular intensity to the participle, reducing the valor of the
verb as action and shifting the participle towards the adjectival sphere. In simplest words, and with an
example: in the face of "He has extinguished-M the cigarette", mere action, "He has extinguished-F the
cigarette" turns to signify nearly "He holds extinguished-F the cigarette", that's to say "He has the
cigarette extinguished-F".'

Ripetiamo: è meglio non concordare quando il verbo viene prima del complemento. Ma bisogna tener conto di una sfumatura di pensiero e di stile. Se nella costruzione normale verbo + complemento si ha la concordanza, può darsi che l'autore abbia voluto dare una particolare intensità al participio, diminuendo il valore del verbo come azione e spostando il participio verso la sfera dell'aggettivo. In parole piú semplici, e con un esempio: di fronte a "Egli ha spento la sigaretta", azione pura, "Egli ha spenta la sigaretta" viene a significare quasi "Egli tiene spenta la sigaretta", cioè "Egli ha la sigaretta spenta".

We repeat: it's better to not agree when the verb comes before the complement. But one has to consider a shade of thought and style. If in the normal construct verb + complement one finds agreement, it can be the case that the author wished to give a particular intensity to the participle, reducing the valor of the verb as action and shifting the participle towards the adjectival sphere. In simplest words, and with an

lexicalization: there are thus no FC PIs in this category. The same holds for CPs.
See the discussion in II.3.1.2.9.2 about the idiomaticity effects of French sans and Italian senza.

tier.item: b. ü Je (ne) vois {* pas/ plus} rien.
Serge Gainsbourg, L'herbe tendre, Philips, 1968.
It is consistent with the observation of Déprez [2000:258], "N-words with a null determiner [nouns, under our
analysis] are essentially predicted to require the presence of negation, and N-words with a filled determiner
[determiners and quantifiers, under our analysis] to preclude it [p. 258]".
A Generic pronoun, typically on `one', is requested by {=Specific, -Generic} NPIs. See II.3.1.1.1.2 and
© 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier - 125 -
A FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA

`I didn't see anything anymore.'

tier.item: (II) COMPOUNDED COMPLEMENTIZER:
a. ü A moins {que/ de}.
To less {that/ of}.
Besides its complementizer-like guise with fear-verbs, ne was also an affirmative particle signifying `indeed'
or `I do', and an enclitic interrogative particle; the interrogative guise of ne modifies the complementizer-like
one in quin, as non does.
© 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier - 150 -
A FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA

tier.item: (III) SEMI-MODALS:
a. ü Pierre n'ose venir.
b. ü Pierre (n')ose pas venir.
The semi-modal class probably consists of lexical verbs marginally able to be generated in functional heads,
besides a regular lexical use (for instance, such a functional head could be Mood Ability for oser `to dare', which is
normally generated inside as a lexical verb inside VP).
© 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier - 197 -
A FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA

tier.item: i. ? Non-ingénieusement.
We quote from top to bottom the hierarchy from the draft of Cinque [1999:178] with `negative' French
counterparts, omitting compounded adverbs like peut-être `perhaps', à nouveau `again' or à peine `just', since
their idiomaticity prevents any prefixation.
© 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier - 200 -
A FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA

tier.item: (544) a. * Zéro chose a été faite par Pierre.
See also Haegeman [1996] about the different properties of N-words and null numerals.
Null quantity doesn't tolerate the Presuppositional feature, hence the incompatibility with the SM, which is
{-Presuppositional}, and need thus another Presuppositional item like the `negative' items.
One could think that plural agreement with `zero' follows from the linguistic meaning of cardinal numbers,
which is `at least n' and not `exactly n', according to De Cornulier [1985:94-97]; if it were true, `one' too would
request plural agreement.
© 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier - 204 -
A FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
Zero thing has been done by Peter.

tier.item: (550) [Aucun] ne prend plus guère la marque du pluriel que devant un nom qui n'a pas de singulier, ou qui a au
pluriel un sens particulier: Aucuns frais. Aucuns faux frais. On ne lui fit aucunes funérailles (Lar. du XXe
s.). Aucunes troupes.
`[No-one] did not much take anymore the plural mark but before a noun lacking a singular form, or
having at the plural a particular meaning: No-M-PL charges. No-M-PL incidental charges. One didn't make
him any-F-PL obsequies (Larousse of the XXth century). No-F-PL troops.'
(550) [Aucun] ne prend plus guère la marque du pluriel que devant un nom qui n'a pas de singulier, ou qui a au
pluriel un sens particulier: Aucuns frais. Aucuns faux frais. On ne lui fit aucunes funérailles (Lar. du XXe
s.). Aucunes troupes.
`[No-one] did not much take anymore the plural mark but before a noun lacking a singular form, or
having at the plural a particular meaning: No-M-PL charges. No-M-PL incidental charges. One didn't make
him any-F-PL obsequies (Larousse of the XXth century). No-F-PL troops.'

[Aucun] ne prend plus guère la marque du pluriel que devant un nom qui n'a pas de singulier, ou qui a au pluriel un sens particulier: Aucuns frais. Aucuns faux frais. On ne lui fit aucunes funérailles (Lar. du XXe s.). Aucunes troupes.

[No-one] did not much take anymore the plural mark but before a noun lacking a singular form, or having at the plural a particular meaning: No-M-PL charges. No-M-PL incidental charges. One didn't make him any-F-PL obsequies (Larousse of the XXth century). No-F-PL troops.

tier.item: (570) Potrei, oltre a questo, d'un altro uso ancora della mia lingua d'intorno al medesimo articolo, quando egli
al secondo caso si dà, non piú del maschio che della femina, ragionarvi; il quale è che alle volte si pon
detto articolo con alquante voci, e con alquante altre non si pone: Il mortaio della pietra, La corona dello
alloro, Le colonne del porfido, e d'altra parte: Ad ora di mangiare et Essendo arche grandi di marmo
[...]. [...] La ragione della differenza, messer Ercole, brievemente è questa; che quando alla voce, che
dinanzi a queste voci del secondo caso si sta o dee stare, delle quali essa è voce, si dànno gli articoli, diate
eziandio gli articoli ad esse voci; quando poi allei gli articoli non si dànno, e voi a queste voci non gli
diate altresí [...].
`I could further reason about another use of my tongue around the same determiner, when it stays at
genitive case, either at the masculine or at the feminine; namely that sometimes one puts that determiner
with some words, and with some other one doesn't put it: The mortar of the stone, The corona of the bay
leaves, The columns of the porphyry, and on the other hand: At time of eaten and Being big arches of
marble [...]. [...] The reason of the difference, mister Hercules, briefly is the following; when to the
word, which before those words at genitive stays or has to stay, whose it is a form, one puts the
determiners, give also the determiners to those words; when one doesn't put the determiners to them, then
you to those words don't put them no longer [...].'
(570) Potrei, oltre a questo, d'un altro uso ancora della mia lingua d'intorno al medesimo articolo, quando egli
al secondo caso si dà, non piú del maschio che della femina, ragionarvi; il quale è che alle volte si pon
detto articolo con alquante voci, e con alquante altre non si pone: Il mortaio della pietra, La corona dello
alloro, Le colonne del porfido, e d'altra parte: Ad ora di mangiare et Essendo arche grandi di marmo
[...]. [...] La ragione della differenza, messer Ercole, brievemente è questa; che quando alla voce, che
dinanzi a queste voci del secondo caso si sta o dee stare, delle quali essa è voce, si dànno gli articoli, diate
eziandio gli articoli ad esse voci; quando poi allei gli articoli non si dànno, e voi a queste voci non gli
diate altresí [...].
`I could further reason about another use of my tongue around the same determiner, when it stays at
genitive case, either at the masculine or at the feminine; namely that sometimes one puts that determiner
with some words, and with some other one doesn't put it: The mortar of the stone, The corona of the bay
leaves, The columns of the porphyry, and on the other hand: At time of eaten and Being big arches of
marble [...]. [...] The reason of the difference, mister Hercules, briefly is the following; when to the
word, which before those words at genitive stays or has to stay, whose it is a form, one puts the
determiners, give also the determiners to those words; when one doesn't put the determiners to them, then
you to those words don't put them no longer [...].'

Potrei, oltre a questo, d'un altro uso ancora della mia lingua d'intorno al medesimo articolo, quando egli al secondo caso si dà, non piú del maschio che della femina, ragionarvi; il quale è che alle volte si pon detto articolo con alquante voci, e con alquante altre non si pone: Il mortaio della pietra, La corona dello alloro, Le colonne del porfido, e d'altra parte: Ad ora di mangiare et Essendo arche grandi di marmo [...]. [...] La ragione della differenza, messer Ercole, brievemente è questa; che quando alla voce, che dinanzi a queste voci del secondo caso si sta o dee stare, delle quali essa è voce, si dànno gli articoli, diate eziandio gli articoli ad esse voci; quando poi allei gli articoli non si dànno, e voi a queste voci non gli diate altresí [...].

I could further reason about another use of my tongue around the same determiner, when it stays at genitive case, either at the masculine or at the feminine; namely that sometimes one puts that determiner with some words, and with some other one doesn't put it: The mortar of the stone, The corona of the bay leaves, The columns of the porphyry, and on the other hand: At time of eaten and Being big arches of marble [...]. [...] The reason of the difference, mister Hercules, briefly is the following; when to the word, which before those words at genitive stays or has to stay, whose it is a form, one puts the determiners, give also the determiners to those words; when one doesn't put the determiners to them, then you to those words don't put them no longer [...].

tier.item: (609) Cloud a au moins zéro dent [sic]: la bizarrerie introduite par au moins dans cet énoncé pourrait suggérer
que zéro, quoique construit sans ne, a comme ne... aucun une valeur intrinsèquement restrictive; mais
l'information que "Cloud a zéro dent [sic]" serait forcément vide, tout nombre possible de dents se situant
entre zéro et au-dessus; zéro se combine bien avec au moins dans Maintenant qu'il fait au moins zéro
degré [sic], on peut sortir sans se geler, où l'information n'est pas nulle parce que le nombre de degrés
peut être inférieur à zéro.
`Cloud has at least zero teeth: the oddity introduced by at least in this utterance might be suggest that
zero, although built without ne, has like ne... aucun an intrinsically restrictive [= `negative'] value; but
the information that "Cloud has zero teeth" should inevitably be vacuous, every possible teeth number
being included between zero and more; zero combines goodly with at least in Now that it's at least zero
degrees centigrade, we can go out without freezing, where the information is not null because the number
of degrees centigrade can be lower than zero.'

a. ü Jeanne est toujours {pétée/ stone /513 shootée }.
b. ü Jeanne (n')est jamais {pétée/ * stone/ * shootée}.

rock-opera written by Michel Berger and Luc Plamondon; it was probably already widespread in Quebec since a
while.

tier.item: (734) a. J "Le glutmich du carbiquet présente des symptômes de dépression à fluctuations antihistaminiques
et paradoxales!... C'est sûrement dû au galvanisateur du patchbull de la réserve de zizanium!...// Ça y
est!... J'ai trouvé!... C'est une protubérance hernieuse à tendance excentrique dans le flexible du
malaxeur de youplalat!..." 516
The glutmich of-the carbicket presents of-the symptoms of depression to fluctuations antihistaminic and
paradoxical!... It is surely due to-the galvanizator of-the patchbull of the reserve of zizanium!...// It LOC
is!... I have found!... This is a protuberance herniary to tendency eccentric in the flexible of-the mixer of
huplala!...
`The glutmich of the carbicket presents the symptoms of a depression with antihistaminic and paradoxical
fluctuations! It's certainly due to the galvanizator of the zizanium reserve's patchbull!// Here I am! This is
a herniary protuberance with eccentric tendency in the flexible of the huplala mixer!'

tier.item: (xcvi) "A tous ceux qui, au nom d'une écologie raciale, parlent de `nettoyer' leur environnement, je dédie
ce conte. Ils apprendront ainsi que, comme Monsieur Jourdain parlait en prose sans le savoir, ils
parlent arabe, hébreu, hindi, malais, algonquin, nahuatl et même chinois, sans le vouloir."
`For all those wanting to `clean' their environment in the name of a racial ecology, I dedicate this
tale to. It will then come to their knowledge that as Monsieur Jourdain was speaking in prose
without realizing, they speak Arabic, Hebrew, Hindi, Malaysian, Algonquin, Nahuatl and even
Greek [literally: Chinese], without wanting.'
(xcvi) "A tous ceux qui, au nom d'une écologie raciale, parlent de `nettoyer' leur environnement, je dédie
ce conte. Ils apprendront ainsi que, comme Monsieur Jourdain parlait en prose sans le savoir, ils
parlent arabe, hébreu, hindi, malais, algonquin, nahuatl et même chinois, sans le vouloir."
`For all those wanting to `clean' their environment in the name of a racial ecology, I dedicate this
tale to. It will then come to their knowledge that as Monsieur Jourdain was speaking in prose
without realizing, they speak Arabic, Hebrew, Hindi, Malaysian, Algonquin, Nahuatl and even
Greek [literally: Chinese], without wanting.'

"A tous ceux qui, au nom d'une écologie raciale, parlent de `nettoyer' leur environnement, je dédie ce conte. Ils apprendront ainsi que, comme Monsieur Jourdain parlait en prose sans le savoir, ils parlent arabe, hébreu, hindi, malais, algonquin, nahuatl et même chinois, sans le vouloir."

For all those wanting to`clean' their environment in the name of a racial ecology, I dedicate this tale to. It will then come to their knowledge that as Monsieur Jourdain was speaking in prose without realizing, they speak Arabic, Hebrew, Hindi, Malaysian, Algonquin, Nahuatl and even Greek [literally: Chinese], without wanting.
